list.title: Question 1
list.content:
Below shows a Sankey diagram for an LED.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/32db4f78-02b8-43c8-82fb-6de54d482356/images/0cc12eab-6d49-485c-82a5-a201da16c116/Screenshot%202025-07-02%20at%202.58.46%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

Which of the following shows the percentage efficiency of the LED and the total power input?Percentage efficiencyTotal power input\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}40%40\%40%444W\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}40%40\%40%202020W\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}60%60\%60%444W\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}60%60\%60%202020W
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Total power unput = total power output =12+8=2012\ +\ 8\ =\ 2012+8=20WFor an LED useful energy is visible light energy:Percentage efficiency =Useful energy outputTotal energy input(100)=820(100)=40%\dfrac{\textrm{ Useful energy output}}{\textrm{ Total energy input}}\ (100)\ =\ \dfrac{8}{20}\ (100)\ =\ 40\%Total energy inputUseful energy output​(100)=208​(100)=40%

list.title: Question 2
list.content: Which of the following units is not a unit of power?A.\hspace{1em}WB.\hspace{1em}JC.\hspace{1em}N m s−1^{-1}−1D.\hspace{1em}J s−1^{-1}−1
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The SI unit of power is W and it is defined as J s−1^{-1}−1.Additionally, power can be calculated byP=FvP = FvP=FvWhen units of force and speed are substituted in the equation, the units become\hspace{1.5em}N m s−1^{-1}−1But J is the SI unit of energy.Therefore, the answer is B.

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
A builder uses a block and tackle pulley system to lift a bundle of materials of mass 15 kg to the top of a building of height 6 m in 9 s. What is the power delivered to the bundle? Assumeg=10g=10g=10N kg−1^{-1}−1.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/39d1489c-8ba8-4cb6-8d7b-fe039bac7303/images/94315b8c-73e2-407b-bd29-9b312cbeeda6/PH0125.png)

[Image Source: Block-and-tackle-in-use.svg by Themightyquill licensed under CC BY-SA 4.0]\footnotesize{\textrm{[Image Source: Block-and-tackle-in-use.svg by Themightyquill licensed under CC BY-SA 4.0}]}[Image Source: Block-and-tackle-in-use.svg by Themightyquill licensed under CC BY-SA 4.0]A.\hspace{1em}10 WB.\hspace{1em}17 WC.\hspace{1em}100 WD.\hspace{1em}900 W
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Power=mght=(15kg)(6m)(10N kg−1)9s=100W\begin{aligned}
\textrm{Power} &= \dfrac{mgh}{t}\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
&= \dfrac{(15\textrm{ kg})(6\textrm{ m})(10\textrm{ N kg}^{-1})}{9\textrm{ s}}\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
 &= 100\textrm{ W}\
 \end{aligned}Power​=tmgh​=9s(15kg)(6m)(10N kg−1)​=100W​

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
The figure below shows a Sankey diagram for a small thermal plant. What is the efficiency of the system?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/59cbaf81-366a-4d3b-84b4-81c19240c4a5/images/2e6829ac-2af0-4764-a71e-8c91dc895927/Screenshot%202025-04-03%20at%201.58.29%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

A.\hspace{1em}10%B.\hspace{1em}20%C.\hspace{1em}40%D.\hspace{1em}60%
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:In Sankey diagrams for energy, useful energy is shown as continuing straight while energy losses point downwards.From the Sankey diagram, subtracting the value of the heat losses givesTo find the useful power:1600−(320+640)=6401600 - (320 + 640) = 6401600−(320+640)=640kWEfficiency can now be calculated:η=Useful power outTotal power in×100=640kW1600kW×100%=40%\begin{aligned}
\hspace{2em}\eta &= \frac{\textrm{Useful power out}}{\textrm{Total power in}} \times 100\\
\hspace{1em}\\
&= \frac{640\textrm{ kW}}{1600\textrm{ kW}} \times 100\% \\
\hspace{1em}\\
&= 40\%
\end{aligned}η​=Total power inUseful power out​×100=1600kW640kW​×100%=40%​

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
An object of massMMMon a string moves in a circle of radiusrrrat a constant speed.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6590a45d-55a7-400f-b7b5-4f31b825e7ad/images/ab24556d-04d2-418a-b7f4-9e1ca037a3f1/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%202.28.54%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Below are three statements about the motion of the object:I.\hspace{1.1em}The resultant work done on the object is zero.II.\hspace{0.8em}The velocity of the object is constant.III.\hspace{0.5em}The object is acceleratingWhich of the statements is/are true?A.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}II onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I and III only
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:I is correct.The accelerating force is always perpendicular to the direction of motion, therefore no work is done.W=Fscos⁡θW = Fs \cos\thetaW=Fscosθ, andθ\thetaθis always 90°\degree°, andcos⁡90°=0\cos 90 \degree =0cos90°=0Also,W=ΔEkW=\Delta E_kW=ΔEk​and the speed of the object is constant so there is no change in kinetic energy.II is incorrect.Because velocity is a vector quantity and the direction is constantly changing, velocity is not constant.III is correct.Because velocity is constantly changing, the object is always accelerating.

list.title: Question 6
list.content: A box is pulled by a child with a horizontal force of 5 N. The box moves a horizontal distance of 4 m in a time of 2 s. What is the average power delivered by the child to the box?A.\hspace{1em}2.5 WB.\hspace{1em}5.0 WC.\hspace{1em}10 WD.\hspace{1em}40 W
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Power =ΔWt\dfrac{\Delta W}{t}tΔW​andW=FsW = FsW=FsW=(5N)(4m)=20W = (5\ \ce{ N})(4\ \ce{m}) = 20W=(5N)(4m)=20JP=20J2s=10P=\dfrac{20\textrm{ J}}{2\textrm{ s}} = 10P=2s20J​=10WAlternative:Pav=Fvav=F(st)=5(42)=10P_{av} = Fv_{av} = F\bigg(\dfrac{\textrm{s}}{\textrm{t}}\bigg) = 5\bigg(\dfrac{4}{2}\bigg) = 10Pav​=Fvav​=F(ts​)=5(24​)=10W

list.title: Question 7
list.content: Which of the following is not appropriate for measuring energy?A.\hspace{1em}JB.\hspace{1em}N mC.\hspace{1em}kg m s−2^{-2}−2D.\hspace{1em}kg m2^{2}2s−2^{-2}−2
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:A. J (joule) is an accepted unit of energyB. Can be shown to represent energy using the work formula:W=FsW=FsW=Fs; in terms of units, 1 J = 1  N mC. Can analysed using Newton's Second LawF=maF=maF=ma; in terms of units, 1 N = 1 kg m s−2^{-2}−2. This is a unit of force not a unit of energy and therefore thecorrect‾\underline{\textrm{correct}}correct​answer.D. Can be shown to represent energy using work and Newton's Second Law:W=Fs=masW = Fs = masW=Fs=mas; In terms of units,
J = N m = kg m s−2^{-2}−2m = kg m2^{2}2s−2^{-2}−2

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
The Sankey diagram below shows the energy degraded at different stages of a nuclear power plant.Which of the following sections corresponds to the stage with the highest energy degradation?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/db5024fd-1b28-45ad-a251-ca5baea6bb09/images/8565468f-e12a-4875-8ebe-e68ae78f9fc8/PH0139.png)
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The arrows that turn downwards represent energy degradation. The widths are proportional to the amount of energy in that stage. The widest of these is B.

list.title: Question 9
list.content: A coin is tossed vertically upwards from an original height of1.51.51.5m above the ground. What is the maximum height reachedabove the groundif the coin was projected with an initial velocity of 3.0 m s−1^{-1}−1?  (Takeg=10g=10g=10m s−2^{-2}−2)A.0.45\hspace{1em} 0.450.45mB.1.50\hspace{1em} 1.501.50mC.1.95\hspace{1em} 1.951.95mD.6.00\hspace{1em} 6.006.00m
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Solution 1:Maximum height occurs when the final speedvvvis zero. The height reached above hands=v2−u22as=0−9−20=0.45m\begin{aligned}
\ s &= \dfrac{v^2 - u^2}{2a}\\
\ s&=\dfrac{0-9}{-20} \\
\ &= 0.45\textrm{ m}\\
\end{aligned}ss​=2av2−u2​=−200−9​=0.45m​To find maximum height above the ground,0.450.450.45m+1.5+\ 1.5+1.5m = 1.95 mSolution 2:Using conservation of energy, kinetic energy is converted completely into gravitational potential energy at the top of the motion12mv2=mgh\dfrac{1}{2} mv^2 = mgh21​mv2=mgh12(3)2=10h\dfrac{1}{2} (3)^2 = 10h21​(3)2=10hh=0.45h=0.45h=0.45mTo find maximum height above the ground,0.450.450.45m+1.5+\ 1.5+1.5m = 1.95 m

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
State the law of conservation of momentum.[2]A stationary body explodes into two pieces of mass asm1m_1m1​andm2m_2m2​in opposite directions.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/429bf6fe-dca5-47bd-b7e0-b199cab3baa5/images/eb3d1823-146c-4af3-9a6b-1e4afd9aafe7/PH0463.png)

Just after the explosion, the ratio of the kinetic energy ofm1m_1m1​to the kinetic energy ofm2m_2m2​is found to be 9. Calculate the ratio of massesm1m2\dfrac{m_1}{m_2}m2​m1​​.[2]
list.markScheme: When the net force on a system is zero / the system is isolated✓\checkmark✓The momentum of the system does not change / the total momentum is constant✓\checkmark✓The magnitude of the momentum of the pieces is equal✓\checkmark✓≪p22m1p22m2=9≫\ll \dfrac{\frac{p^2}{2m_1}}{\frac{p^2}{2m_2}} = 9 \gg≪2m2​p2​2m1​p2​​=9≫m1m2=19✓\dfrac{m_1}{m_2} = \dfrac{1}{9}\,\checkmarkm2​m1​​=91​✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Since the body is at rest, the total momentum before the explosion is zero. Due to the conservation of momentum, total momentum after the collision must be zero. The two pieces move in the opposite directions. Therefore, the magnitude of momentum they possess must be the same to cancel each other. The ratio of kinetic energies;p22m1p22m2=9\dfrac{\frac{p^2}{2m_1}}{\frac{p^2}{2m_2}} = 92m2​p2​2m1​p2​​=9m2m1=9\dfrac{m_2}{m_1} = 9m1​m2​​=9Therefore,m1m2=19\dfrac{m_1}{m_2} = \dfrac{1}{9}m2​m1​​=91​

list.title: Question 11
list.content:
A spring with spring constantkkkis extended by a distancexxx.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/75c10d0f-876b-4ad3-8025-7af70691d5b7/images/b7cb87cb-4bf9-4e63-9b30-1a5a397b29ca/Screenshot%202025-04-07%20at%208.19.25%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

[Created using Geogebra https://www.geogebra.org/m/vUK7gGkN]\small{\textrm{[Created using Geogebra https://www.geogebra.org/m/vUK7gGkN]}}[Created using Geogebra https://www.geogebra.org/m/vUK7gGkN]The uncertainty ofkkkis 2% and that ofxxxis 3%.What is the uncertainty of the potential energy stored in the spring?A.\hspace{1em}8%B.\hspace{1em}11%C.\hspace{1em}12%D.\hspace{1em}18%
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The formula for potential energy stored isEH=12kx2E_H=\dfrac{1}{2}kx^2EH​=21​kx2SinceEHE_HEH​is calculated from multiplyingkkkandx2x^2x2(ignoring the constant12\frac{1}{2}21​as there is no uncertainty for it), then the uncertainty ofEHE_HEH​is calculated by adding the fractional uncertainties ofx2x^2x2andkkk.The fractional uncertainty ofx2x^2x2is double the fractional uncertainty onxxx, which gives2×3%=6%2\times3\% = 6\%2×3%=6%The uncertainty ofEPE_PEP​therefore2% + 6% = 8%

list.title: Question 12
list.content:
A box of massmmmis pulled across a horizontal surface with a forceFFFas shown in the diagram. The coefficient of dynamic friction between the box and the surface isμ\muμ. What is the energy transferred to thermal energy while a box is moved by a distance ofddd?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d68b186d-1f20-40cd-babc-b130ca4c968e/images/195ea83c-ec2e-42af-aa16-8f5e1a02e01e/Screenshot%202025-04-07%20at%2011.10.31%E2%80%AFAM2.JPEG)

A.\hspace{1em}FdFdFdB.\hspace{1em}(F−μmg)d(F-\mu mg)d(F−μmg)dC.\hspace{1em}μmgd\mu mgdμmgdD.\hspace{1em}mgdmgdmgd
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Energy transferred to thermal energy will be the work done by the frictional force.FF=μFN=μmgF_F=\mu F_N = \mu mgFF​=μFN​=μmg(whereFN=mgF_N=mgFN​=mg)W=Fs=μmgdW = Fs = \mu mgdW=Fs=μmgd

list.title: Question 13
list.content:
A block of mass 16 kg is pushed and released along a rough horizontal surface at an initial speed of 2 m s−1^{-1}−1.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7c45a6b1-fd52-47f4-87cf-51ddb2c7383c/images/0f148f8c-b290-441d-943e-e1bc0eba3a33/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%202.30.42%E2%80%AFPM.png)

The block travels through a distance of 16 m and is brought to rest. What is the magnitude of the frictional force that brings the block to rest?A.\hspace{1em}2 NB.\hspace{1em}4 NC.\hspace{1em}8 ND.\hspace{1em}16 N
list.markScheme:
AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The net work done on the block= Change in kinetic energy of the blockWnet=ΔEkFscos⁡(θ)=12m(vf)2−12m(vi)2Fscos⁡(θ)=0−12m(vi)2(F)(16)(cos⁡180o)=−12(16)(2)2(F)(16)(−1)=−32F=2N\begin{aligned}
 W_{net}&=\Delta E_k \\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 Fs \cos(\theta)& = \frac{1}{2}m(v_f)^2 - \frac{1}{2}m(v_i)^2 \\
\hspace{1em}\\Fs\cos(\theta) &= 0 -\frac{1}{2}m(v_i)^2 \\
\hspace{1em}\\
(F)(16)(\cos\,180^o)&=-\frac{1}{2}(16)(2)^2 \\
\hspace{1em}\\
(F)(16)(-1)&=-32 \\
\hspace{1em}\\
F&=2\textrm{ N}\
\end{aligned}Wnet​Fscos(θ)Fscos(θ)(F)(16)(cos180o)(F)(16)(−1)F​=ΔEk​=21​m(vf​)2−21​m(vi​)2=0−21​m(vi​)2=−21​(16)(2)2=−32=2N​Alternative:v2=u2+2as⇒a=v2−u22s=02−222(16)=−0.125v^2 = u^2 + 2as \Rightarrow a = \dfrac{v^2 - u^2}{2s} = \dfrac{0^2 - 2^2}{2(16)} = -0.125v2=u2+2as⇒a=2sv2−u2​=2(16)02−22​=−0.125m s−2^{-2}−2∣F∣=m∣a∣=16∣−0.125∣=2|F| = m|a| = 16|-0.125| = 2∣F∣=m∣a∣=16∣−0.125∣=2N

list.title: Question 14
list.content: The engine of a racing  car provides a forward thrust of 800 N. The average of the total resistive forces acting on the car is 300 N and the car covers a distance of 1.0 km in 10 s.What is the average power input of the engine?A.5.0×103\hspace{1em}  	5.0\times{10}^35.0×103WB.8.0×103\hspace{1em}  	8.0\times{10}^38.0×103WC.5.0×104\hspace{1em}  	5.0\times{10}^45.0×104WD.8.0×104\hspace{1em}  8.0\times{10}^48.0×104W
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The distance covered by the car in meters;1km=10001\ \ce{km}=10001km=1000mThe average speedvavv_{av}vav​of the car;vav=st=1000m10s=100v_{av}=\dfrac{s}{t}=\dfrac{1000\textrm{ m}}{10\textrm{ s}}=100vav​=ts​=10s1000m​=100m s−1^{-1}−1The average output powerPavP_{av}Pav​of the engine;Pav=FvavP_{av}=Fv_{av} \hspace{2em}Pav​=Fvav​whereF=800\hspace{2em}F=800F=800N since it is the force of the enginePav=(800)(100)=8.0×104P_{av}=\left(800\right)\left(100\right)=8.0\times{10}^4Pav​=(800)(100)=8.0×104WNote that this power from the engine does not all contribute to the kinetic energy of the car, as some of it is used to overcome the resistive forces.

list.title: Question 15
list.content: An electric motor is used to raise a block of mass 18.0 kg vertically to the top of a building at a constant speed of 1.5 m s−1^{-1}−1. If the power rating of the motor is 297 W, calculate the efficiency of the motor. Assumeg=10g=10g=10N kg−1^{-1}−1.A.\hspace{1em}9%B.\hspace{1em}75%C.\hspace{1em}61%D.\hspace{1em}91%
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Efficiency is the ratio of power output to power input expressed as a percentage.Pinput=297P_{input} = 297Pinput​=297WForce =mg=(18kg)(10N kg−1)=180mg = (18\textrm{ kg})(10\textrm{ N kg}^{-1})= 180mg=(18kg)(10N kg−1)=180NPoutputP_{output}Poutput​= (Force)(Velocity) =(180N)(1.50m)1s\dfrac{(180\textrm{ N})(1.50\textrm{ m})}{1\textrm{ s}}1s(180N)(1.50m)​= 270 WEfficiency=PoweroutputPowerinput×100Efficiency=\dfrac{Power\,output}{Power\,input} \times 100Efficiency=PowerinputPoweroutput​×100η=270W297W×\eta = \dfrac{270\,\ce{W}}{297\,\ce{W}}\,\timesη=297W270W​×100% = 91%

list.title: Question 16
list.content:
An object of mass222kg with initial kinetic energy101010J comes to rest as it travels a distance of333m along a flat horizontal rough surface as shown in the diagram below.

list.markScheme: AExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​Kinetic energy is transferred to work done (by friction)ΔEK=Ffs=(μFN)s=(μdmg)s\Delta E_K = F_f s = (\mu F_N)s =(\mu_dmg)sΔEK​=Ff​s=(μFN​)s=(μd​mg)sSubstituting the given values leads to10=μd(2)(10)(3)10 = \mu_d(2)(10)(3)10=μd​(2)(10)(3)1=μd(2)(3)1 = \mu_d(2)(3)1=μd​(2)(3)μd=16\mu_d = \dfrac{1}{6}μd​=61​

list.title: Question 18
list.content:
A spring of mass m is compressed against a block of mass2m2m2mon a frictionless surface. The system is held stationary and the elastic potential energy stored in spring isEHE_HEH​.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/04be70e3-9fb6-45cf-81d3-0066e5826298/images/ae44405c-172d-46c3-9b47-ee19e589be98/Screenshot%202025-06-04%20at%209.31.08%E2%80%AFAM.png)

[Source: Created with chemix - https://chemix.org/]\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Created with chemix - https://chemix.org/]}}[Source: Created with chemix - https://chemix.org/]The system is released and the block and spring move horizontally. All of the elastic potential energy of the spring is converted into kinetic energy of the system.Show that after the system is released, the speed of the blockvbv_bvb​is given by the equation:vb=EH3mv_b=\sqrt{\dfrac{E_H}{3m}}vb​=3mEH​​​[3]The following data are given:Mass of springm=120m=120m=120gSpring constant of springk=85k=85k=85N m−2^{-2}−2Initial compression of the springx=8.0x=8.0x=8.0cmCalculatevbv_bvb​.[2]The block moves onto a surface where the coefficient of dynamic friction between the block and the ground isμd=0.07\mu_d=0.07μd​=0.07. When the block is at pointAAAits velocity is0.710.710.71m s−1^{-1}−1. The block comes at a complete stop at pointBBB.

However, when the object is at rest, the static frictional force prevents it from moving.Static friction can take any value up to its maximum limit, which is given by:Ff=μsFNF_f=\mu_sF_NFf​=μs​FN​whereμs\mu_sμs​is the coefficient of static friction andFNF_NFN​is the normal reaction force.The coefficient of static friction is greater than the coefficient of dynamic friction, so the maximum static frictional force is also greater than the dynamic frictional force. This means that more force is required to start on object moving from rest than is required to keep it moving at a constant speed against a dynamic frictional force.

list.title: Question 23
list.content: Energy density is defined as the amount of energy stored in a substance per unit volume. Amounts of substances A and B are employed to supply the same average power to a city over an identical time period. The densities of these substances areρ\rhoρand2ρ2\rho2ρ, respectively, with their respective volumes being2V2V2VandVVV. Consider the following statements:I.A greater mass was used than substance BII.It has a lower energy density than substance BIII.It provided the same amount of energy as substance BWhich statement is/are correct for substance A and the amount of it used in the time period?A.\hspace{1em}III onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II, and III
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The mass of substances can be determined by multiplying their density and volume, ensuring their masses are equal. Since both substances provide the same average of power over the same time, they provide the same amount of energy. (E=PtE=PtE=Pt)Energy density can be calculated byEnergy density =energy providedvolume\dfrac{\textrm{energy provided}}{\textrm{volume}}volumeenergy provided​While both provide the same amount of energy, Substance B has a smaller volume compared to Substance A. Consequently, Substance A possesses a lower energy density.

list.content:
Define momentum.[1]A golf ball of mass 45 g moving with a constant velocity of 2.0 m s−1^{-1}−1undergoes a head-on collision with a stationary ball of mass 2.0 kg. The line that joins the centres of the balls is along the direction of the velocity of the golf ball.

Use Newton's Third Law and Second Law to deduce why the change in momentum of the golf ball is equal and opposite to the change in momentum of the stationary ball during the collision.[3]The variation of force acting on the golf ballFFFwith the timetttduring the collision is shown in the graph.

Show that the magnitude of the change in momentum of the golf ball is approximately 0.09 kg m s−1^{-1}−1.[2]Calculate the speed of the golf ball just after the collision.[3]Discuss whether the collision is elastic or inelastic.[4]
list.markScheme:
The product of mass and velocity.✓\checkmark✓According to Newton's third Law, the force acting on the golf ball equals and is opposite to the force acting on the stationary ball/Fg=−FsF_g=-F_sFg​=−Fs​✓\checkmark✓According to Newton's Second Law, the net force equals the rate of change in momentum/ΔpgΔt=−ΔpsΔt\dfrac{\Delta p_g}{\Delta t}=-\dfrac{\Delta p_s}{\Delta t}ΔtΔpg​​=−ΔtΔps​​✓\checkmark✓Since the time of collision is the same for both of the objects, changes in momenta are equal but in opposite directions/ sinceΔt\Delta tΔtfor each ball is equal,Δpg=−Δps\Delta p_g=-\Delta p_sΔpg​=−Δps​✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:According to Newton's third law, the force acting on the golf ballFgF_gFg​equals and is opposite to the force acting on the stationary ballFsF_sFs​during the collision.Fg=−FsF_g=-F_sFg​=−Fs​According to Newton's Second Law, the net force equals the rate of change in momentum. Therefore, the rate of change in momentum of the ballΔpgΔt\dfrac{\Delta p_g}{\Delta t}ΔtΔpg​​equals and is opposite to the rate of change of momentum in the stationary ballΔpsΔt\dfrac{\Delta p_s}{\Delta t}ΔtΔps​​.ΔpgΔt=−ΔpsΔt\dfrac{\Delta p_g}{\Delta t}=-\dfrac{\Delta p_s}{\Delta t}ΔtΔpg​​=−ΔtΔps​​Since the time of collision is the same for both of the objects, changes in momenta are equal but in opposite directions.Area under the graph = impulse / change in momentum✓\checkmark✓change in momentum =12(2.4)(72×10−3)=0.086kg m s−1\dfrac{1}{2}(2.4)(72 \times 10^{-3}) = \answer{0.086\ \textrm{kg m s}^{-1}}21​(2.4)(72×10−3)=0.086kg m s−1​✓\checkmark✓(extra significant figures must be shown to receive full marks)Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The area under the “Force acting on the object” “Time of acting force” graph equals the impulse and also the change in momentum. Therefore, the area of the triangleAtA_tAt​should be calculated to get the change in momentumΔp\Delta pΔp;Δp=At=12bh=12(2.4)(72×10−3)=0.086kg m s−1\begin{aligned}
 \Delta p &= A_t\\
  &= \dfrac{1}{2}bh\\ 
  &= \dfrac{1}{2}(2.4)(72 \times 10^{-3})\\
  &=0.086\textrm{ kg m s}^{-1}
  \end{aligned}Δp​=At​=21​bh=21​(2.4)(72×10−3)=0.086kg m s−1​Use ofΔp=mv−mu\Delta p=mv-muΔp=mv−mu✓\checkmark✓−0.086=(45×10−3)v−(45×10−3)(2.0)-0.086=(45 \times 10^{-3})v-(45 \times 10^{-3})(2.0)−0.086=(45×10−3)v−(45×10−3)(2.0)✓\checkmark✓(negative sign on change in momentum must be seen)v=≪4×10−345×10−3≫=0.089m s−1v=\ll \dfrac{4 \times 10^{-3}}{45 \times 10^{-3}}\gg= \answer{0.089\textrm{ m s}^{-1}}v=≪45×10−34×10−3​≫=0.089m s−1​✓\checkmark✓Note: Use of 0.09 kg m s−1^{-1}−1gives a final speed of 0 m s−1^{-1}−1. This is accepted if full working is shown.Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The force acting on the golf ball during the collision is towards the left. Hence, the change in momentum of the golf ball must be towards the left. When left is chosen as negative and right is chosen as positive for the vectors, the following relationship can be written for change in momentum;Δp=mv−mu\Delta p=mv-muΔp=mv−muwhereΔp=−0.086\Delta p=-0.086Δp=−0.086kg m s−1^{-1}−1,m=45×10−3m=45\times10^{-3}m=45×10−3kg,u=2.0u=2.0u=2.0m s−1^{-1}−1, andv=v=v=final velocity after the collision.−0.086=(45×10−3)v−(45×10−3)(2.0)(90×10−3)−0.086=(45×10−3)v4×10−3=(45×10−3)v4×10−345×10−3=v0.089m s−1=v\begin{aligned}
 -0.086&=(45 \times 10^{-3})v-(45 \times 10^{-3})(2.0)\\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 (90 \times 10^{-3})-0.086&=(45 \times 10^{-3})v\\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 4 \times 10^{-3}&=(45 \times 10^{-3})v\\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 \frac{4 \times 10^{-3}}{45 \times 10^{-3}}&=v\\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 0.089\textrm{ m s}^{-1}&=v
 \end{aligned}−0.086(90×10−3)−0.0864×10−345×10−34×10−3​0.089m s−1​=(45×10−3)v−(45×10−3)(2.0)=(45×10−3)v=(45×10−3)v=v=v​Kinetic energy before the collision =12mgug2=12(45×10−3)(2.0)2=0.090\dfrac{1}{2}m_g u_g^2=\dfrac{1}{2}(45 \times 10^{-3})(2.0)^2=0.09021​mg​ug2​=21​(45×10−3)(2.0)2=0.090J✓\checkmark✓Change in momentum of larger ball = 0.086 N sp=mvp = mvp=mv0.086=2.0v0.086=2.0v0.086=2.0vSpeed of the stationary ball after the collision=0.043ms−1=0.043\,\ce{m s}^{-1}=0.043ms−1✓\checkmark✓Correct calculation of final total kinetic energy according to the result of (b)(iii)Etotal=12(45×10−3)(0.089)2+12(2.0)(0.043)2=0.0020E_{total}=\dfrac{1}{2}(45 \times 10^{-3})(0.089)^2+ \dfrac{1}{2}(2.0)(0.043)^2=0.0020Etotal​=21​(45×10−3)(0.089)2+21​(2.0)(0.043)2=0.0020J0.00200.00200.0020J✓\checkmark✓Kinetic energy after is less so the collision is inelastic.✓\checkmark✓Note: A calculation leading to the kinetic energy after being equal to the kinetic energy before and a statement that the collision is elastic would score only one mark total.Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The total kinetic energy of the balls before the collisionEtkbE_{tkb}Etkb​equals the kinetic energy of the golf ball before the collisionEkgbE_{kgb}Ekgb​;Etkb=Ekgb=12mgug2=12(45×10−3)(2.0)2=0.090E_{tkb}=E_{kgb}=\dfrac{1}{2} m_g u_g^2=\dfrac{1}{2}(45 \times 10^{-3})(2.0)^2=0.090Etkb​=Ekgb​=21​mg​ug2​=21​(45×10−3)(2.0)2=0.090JThe speed of the stationary ball after the collision can be found byΔp=mv−mu\Delta p=mv-muΔp=mv−muwhereΔp=0.086\Delta p=0.086Δp=0.086kg m s−1^{-1}−1,m=2.0m=2.0m=2.0kg,u=0u=0u=0m s−1^{-1}−10.086=2.0v0.0862.0=v0.043m s−1=v\begin{aligned}
 \ 0.086 &=2.0v\\
 \ \frac{0.086}{2.0}&= v\\
 \ 0.043\textrm{ m s}^{-1}&=v\\
 \end{aligned}0.0862.00.086​0.043m s−1​=2.0v=v=v​The total kinetic energy of the balls after the collisionEtkaE_{tka}Etka​equals the sum of the kinetic energy of the golfEkgaE_{kga}Ekga​and stationary ballsEksaE_{ksa}Eksa​after the collision;Etka=Ekga+Eksa=12mgvg2+12msvs2=12(45×10−3)(0.089)2+12(2.0)(0.043)2=0.0020J\begin{aligned}
 E_{tka}&=E_{kga}+E_{ksa}\\
 &=\frac{1}{2} m_g v_g^2+\frac{1}{2} m_s v_s^2\\
 &=\frac{1}{2}(45 \times 10^{-3})(0.089)^2+\frac{1}{2}(2.0)(0.043)^2\\
 &=0.0020\textrm{ J}
 \end{aligned}Etka​​=Ekga​+Eksa​=21​mg​vg2​+21​ms​vs2​=21​(45×10−3)(0.089)2+21​(2.0)(0.043)2=0.0020J​Etkb>EtkaE_{tkb}>E_{tka}Etkb​>Etka​, the kinetic energy of the systems is not conserved. Therefore, collision is inelastic.

CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The work done by the spring on the box equals to decrease in elastic potential energyΔEH\mathrm{\Delta}E_HΔEH​of the spring. The initial compression of the spring is666cm and the final compression of the spring is2.02.02.0cm due to a4.04.04.0cm displacement.ΔEH=ΔEH(initial)−ΔEH(final)ΔEH=12(200)(0.062)−12(200)(0.022)ΔEH=(100)(0.062−0.022)ΔEH=(100)(36−410000)=0.32J\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{\Delta}E_H&=\mathrm{\Delta}E_{H(initial)}-\mathrm{\Delta}E_{H\left(final\right)}\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\

\hspace{2.3cm}\\
\mathrm{\Delta}E_H&=\left(100\right) \bigg(\frac{36-4}{10000}\bigg)=0.32 \textrm{ J}\ \
\end{aligned}ΔEH​ΔEH​ΔEH​ΔEH​​=ΔEH(initial)​−ΔEH(final)​=21​(200)(0.062)−21​(200)(0.022)=(100)(0.062−0.022)=(100)(1000036−4​)=0.32J​Therefore, the answer is C.

list.content:
A motorised toy car starts from rest, with the motor delivering increasing power to the car over time as shown in the graph below.

Assuming no energy losses, which of the following gives the kinetic energy of the car after 8.0 seconds?A.\hspace{1em}0.20 JB.\hspace{1em}5.0 JC.\hspace{1em}160 JD.\hspace{1em}320 J
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The energy can be found by calculating the area under the graph.Work done =(Power)(time)2\dfrac{(Power)(time)}{2}2(Power)(time)​W=(40W)(8s)2=160W = \dfrac{(40\textrm{ W})(8\textrm{ s})}{2} = 160W=2(40W)(8s)​=160JAlternative solution:Because Power increases at a constant rate, the average Power (PavP_{av}Pav​) can be found from the average of the starting and ending powers.Pav=0+402=20P_{av} = \dfrac{0+40}{2} = 20Pav​=20+40​=20WE=Pavt=(20)(8)=160E=P_{av}t = (20)(8) = 160E=Pav​t=(20)(8)=160J

list.content: A ball with massmmmis released from a height ofhhhand undergoes free fall. The ball hits the ground and rebounds vertically. On rebound, the ball reaches a maximum height ofh′h'h′. The time taken for the collision isTTT. During the collision, what are the change in kinetic energy of the ball and the magnitude of the average net force on the ball?\hspace{1em}Change in kinetic energy\hspace{1em}\hspace{1em}Average force\hspace{1em}\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}mg(h−h′)mg(h-h')mg(h−h′)m(2gh+2gh′)T\dfrac{m(\sqrt{2gh} + \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}Tm(2gh​+2gh′​)​\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}mg(h′−h)mg(h'-h)mg(h′−h)m(2gh−2gh′)T\dfrac{m(\sqrt{2gh} - \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}Tm(2gh​−2gh′​)​\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}mg(h′−h)mg(h'-h)mg(h′−h)m(2gh+2gh′)T\dfrac{m(\sqrt{2gh} + \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}Tm(2gh​+2gh′​)​\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}mg(h−h′)mg(h-h')mg(h−h′)m(2gh−2gh′)T\dfrac{m(\sqrt{2gh} - \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}Tm(2gh​−2gh′​)​
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Change in kinetic energy  = Loss of mechanical energy = change in potential energy=mgh′−mgh=mg(h′−h)mgh' - mgh = mg(h'-h)mgh′−mgh=mg(h′−h)We can find the velocity before hitting the ground using conservation of energy12mu2=mgh\dfrac{1}{2}mu^2=mgh21​mu2=mghgivingu=2ghu = \sqrt{2gh}u=2gh​Similarly, velocity after bouncing from the groundv=−2gh′v = - \sqrt{2gh'}v=−2gh′​Change in momentumΔp=m(v−u)\Delta p = m (v-u)Δp=m(v−u)=m(−2gh′−2gh)m (-\sqrt{2gh'} - \sqrt{2gh})m(−2gh′​−2gh​)Force is rate of change of momentumFav=−m(2gh+2gh′)TF_{av} = \dfrac{-m(\sqrt{2gh} + \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}Fav​=T−m(2gh​+2gh′​)​Because the question asks for the magnitude of the average force, we can take the positive value.Fav=m(2gh+2gh′)TF_{av} = \dfrac{m(\sqrt{2gh} + \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}Fav​=Tm(2gh​+2gh′​)​

list.title: Question 38
list.content:
A motor uses a cable to pull a trolley up an inclined plane at a constant velocity.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/03c2e4aa-9eff-4287-8eef-0ae906343fba/images/28f10955-8ba2-42e6-b8d5-59a2eaf0a440/ph0035q.JPEG)

Consider the following statements about the energy changes of the trolley during its motion.I.The work done by the engine has greater magnitude than the work done by friction.II.The total of kinetic and potential energy of the trolley increases.III.The gain in gravitational potential energy of the trolley has the same magnitude as the work done by the engine.Of the statements above, which is/are correct?A.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II, and III
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:I.	Correct: as the trolley moves up gravitational potential energy increases so work done by the trolley is done against both friction and gravity.II.	Correct: kinetic energy is constant since trolley is moving at constant velocity but gravitational potential energy increases as height of it from ground increases.III.	Incorrect: some amount of work done by the engine is used to increase gravitational potential energy, but some of it wasted as work done by friction.

list.title: Question 40
list.content: A box of mass222kg is pushed with an initial speed of 10 m s−1^{-1}−1on a rough horizontal floor. A uniform frictional force of101010N acts on the box. What is the distance travelled by the box at the instant when the kinetic energy of the box is halved?A.\hspace{1em}10 mB.\hspace{1em}5 mC.\hspace{1em}2 mD.\hspace{1em}1 m
list.markScheme:
BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The loss of kinetic energy is equal to half of the orinal kinetic energy:Ek(Lost)=Ek(initial)2E_{k(Lost)}= \dfrac{E_{k(initial)}}{2}Ek(Lost)​=2Ek(initial)​​Work done by friction is equal to the loss of kinetic energy.Ek(Lost)=W=FfsE_{k(Lost)} = W = F_fsEk(Lost)​=W=Ff​sEk(initial)2=Ffs\dfrac{E_{k(initial)}}{2} = F_fs2Ek(initial)​​=Ff​sBy substituting given values in the equation usingEk=12mv2E_k=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2Ek​=21​mv2(12)(2)(102)2=10s(12)(100)=10s50=10ss=5\begin{aligned}
\hspace{2em} \bigg(\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg) \dfrac{(2)(10^2)}{2}  &= 10\,s\\
\bigg(\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg)(100) &= 10\,s\\
50 &= 10\,s\\
s &= 5 
\end{aligned}(21​)2(2)(102)​(21​)(100)50s​=10s=10s=10s=5​Therefore, the answer is B.

A cannonball is fired horizontally from a cannon positioned at the edge of a cliff.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/075709d5-6b82-4c14-84e3-4e295554dd8f/images/a8bab8c2-0aad-4a4d-8b10-7371910c8ac9/PH0562zzz.png)

In the context of Newton's Laws, explain why the cannon recoils to the left when the cannonball is fired.[2]The initial recoil speed of the cannon is1.01.01.0m s−1^{-1}−1and its mass is 1200 kg.After the ball is fired, the cannon rolls to the left and experiences a resistive force of8.08.08.0kN as it rolls. Determine the distance covered by the cannon.[2]The mass of the cannonball is9.09.09.0kg. Show that the magnitude of the velocity of the ball after being fired is approximately133133133m s−1^{-1}−1.[2]Calculate the magnitude of the displacement of the cannonball after5.05.05.0s.  Air resistance can be ignored.[3]
list.markScheme: By Newton's 3rd law, there is a force to the right acting on the cannonball✓\checkmark✓There is an equal and opposite force (to the left) on the cannon✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:There is a force acting on the cannonball during the firing. According to Newton's third law, there must be an equal and opposite force on the cannon.a=Fm=80001200=6.7a=\dfrac{F}{m}=\dfrac{8000}{1200}=6.7a=mF​=12008000​=6.7m s−2^{-2}−2s=v22a=1(2)(6.7)=s=\dfrac{v^2}{2a}=\dfrac{1}{(2)(6.7)}=s=2av2​=(2)(6.7)1​=0.074 mFurther Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The decelerationaof the cannon is:a=Fm=80001200=6.7a=\dfrac{F}{m}=\dfrac{8000}{1200}=6.7a=mF​=12008000​=6.7m s−2^{-2}−2The distancescan be calculated using the uniform acceleration equationsv2=u2+2asv^2=u^2+2asv2=u2+2aswherev=0v=0v=0u=1u=1u=1m s−1^{-1}−1a=−6.7a=-6.7a=−6.7m s−2^{-2}−20=12+(2)(−6.7)s0=1^2+(2)(-6.7)s0=12+(2)(−6.7)ss=1(2)(6.7)=0.074s=\dfrac{1}{(2)(6.7)}=0.074s=(2)(6.7)1​=0.074mAny reference to the conservation of momentum✓\checkmark✓v2=(−m1)(v1)m2=−(1200)(1.0)9.0=≪v_2 = \dfrac{(-m_1)(v_1)}{m_2} = \dfrac{-(1200)(1.0)}{9.0} = \llv2​=m2​(−m1​)(v1​)​=9.0−(1200)(1.0)​=≪-133 m s−1≫^{-1} \gg−1≫✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Due to the conservation of momentum, the total momentum of the objects before the firing should be equal to the total momentum of the objects after the firing.The total momentum of the objects before the firing is zero due to the absence of motion. Therefore there total momentum of the objects after firing is also zero0=m1v1+m2v20=m_1v_1+m_2v_20=m1​v1​+m2​v2​wherem1=1200m_1=1200m1​=1200kgv1=1v_1=1v1​=1m s−1^{-1}−1m2=9.0m_2=9.0m2​=9.0kgv2=−m1v1m2=−(1200)(1.0)9.0=−133v_2=\dfrac{{-m}_1v_1}{m_2}=\dfrac{-(1200)(1.0)}{9.0}=-133v2​=m2​−m1​v1​​=9.0−(1200)(1.0)​=−133m s−1^{-1}−1The negative sign represents the direction of the velocity. Therefore it is opposite to the direction of the motion of the cannon.Horizontal displacement=vt=(133)(5.0)=666=vt=\left(133\right)\left(5.0\right)=666=vt=(133)(5.0)=666m✓\checkmark✓Vertical displacement=ut+\fdrac12at2=12(9.81)(52)=122ut+\fdrac{1}{2}at^2=\dfrac{1}{2}\left(9.81\right)\left(5^2\right)=122ut+\fdrac12at2=21​(9.81)(52)=122m✓\checkmark✓Displacement of the cannonball=6662+1222==\sqrt{{666}^2+{122}^2}==6662+1222​=677 m✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Due to the absence of air resistance, the horizontal velocity of the ball is constant and vertical velocity increases with the acceleration of free fall. The horizontal displacementxof the cannonballx=vtx=vtx=vtwherev=133v=133v=133m s−1^{-1}−1andt=3.0t=3.0t=3.0sx=(133)(5.0)=666x=\left(133\right)\left(5.0\right)=666x=(133)(5.0)=666mThe vertical displacementyof the cannonbally=ut+12at2y=ut+\dfrac{1}{2}at^2y=ut+21​at2whereu=0u=0u=0a=9.81a=9.81a=9.81m s−1^{-1}−1t=5.0st=5.0\, st=5.0sy=12(9.81)(52)=122y=\dfrac{1}{2}\left(9.81\right)\left(5^2\right)=122\,y=21​(9.81)(52)=122mThe magnitude of the displacementscan be found by using Pythagoras's theorem;s=x2+y2s=\sqrt{x^2+y^2}s=x2+y2​s=6662+1222=677s=\sqrt{{666}^2+{122}^2}=677s=6662+1222​=677m

list.title: Question 46
list.content:
A system that consists of two light identical springs connected in series stores a total elastic potential energyEpE_pEp​when a load is added to the springs. One of the springs is then removed and the same load is added to the remaining spring.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/33f5116a-a5fd-45d6-9813-47893ca89f34/images/673d5011-a1de-4871-a58f-ca4a34260938/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%202.13.46%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

[Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]\footnotesize{\textrm{[Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]}}[Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]In terms ofEpE_pEp​, what is the total elastic potential energy stored in the single spring situation?A.\hspace{1em}2EpE_pEp​B.\hspace{1em}EpE_pEp​C.\hspace{1em}0.5EpE_pEp​D.\hspace{1em}0.25EpE_pEp​
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Using Hooke's law,F=kΔxF=k\Delta xF=kΔxthe elastic potential energy isEp=12kΔx2=12FΔxE_p=\dfrac{1}{2} k\Delta x^2=\dfrac{1}{2} F\Delta xEp​=21​kΔx2=21​FΔx.In the two-spring situation, both springs have an extension given by the equationF=kΔxF=k\Delta xF=kΔx.When one of the springs is removed, the load remains unchanged and the remaining spring experiences the same extension. Therefore the elastic potential energy stored is also halved.

list.title: Question 47
list.content:
Two blocks of masses 3.0 kg and 4.0 kg are held stationary with a thread connecting the blocks. The mass of 3.0 kg is on a rough incline that makes an angle of 30° with the ground and it starts to slip up when the other mass is slightly more than 4.0 kg.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3e083eeb-2ac3-45c1-a54c-95d8955270d7/images/b43aec29-c2a0-4524-b402-66e35e1e23b1/PH0559MS.png)

State two differences between static friction and dynamic friction[2]Calculate the coefficient of static friction between the mass of 3.0 kg and the rough surface.[3]The thread connecting masses breaks and the mass of 3.0 kg slides down. Show that the acceleration of the mass of 3.0 kg is around 1.5 m s−2^{-2}−2. The coefficient of dynamic friction between 3.0 kg mass and the rough surface is 0.40.[2]Determine the speed of the mass of 3.0 kg after it has moved through a vertical height of 1.0 m.[2]
list.markScheme:
Static friction occurs when the object is not moving (relative to a surface) and Dynamic friction occurs when there is relative motion between the object and a surface✓\checkmark✓The magnitude of static friction is dependent on external forces and the magnitude of dynamic friction is not dependent on external forcesORstatic friction force can vary up to a maximum while dynamic friction is a constant value✓\checkmark✓Component of weight parallel to the incline =≪mgsin⁡(30°)=(3.0)(9.81)(0.5)=≫15≪N≫\ll mg\sin(30°)=(3.0)(9.81)(0.5)=\gg 15 \ll\textrm{N}\gg≪mgsin(30°)=(3.0)(9.81)(0.5)=≫15≪N≫and tension in threadT=mg=(4.0)(9.81)=39T=mg=(4.0)(9.81)=39T=mg=(4.0)(9.81)=39N✓\checkmark✓Static friction =≪39−15=≫24≪N≫\ll 39-15=\gg 24 \ll\textrm{N}\gg≪39−15=≫24≪N≫✓\checkmark✓coefficient of static friction =≪24(3.0)(9.81)cos⁡(30°)=≫\ll \dfrac{24}{(3.0)(9.81)\cos(30°)}= \gg≪(3.0)(9.81)cos(30°)24​=≫0.96✓\checkmark✓(0.94 to 0.96 accepted)Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:According to the diagram, the mass of 3 kg is balanced with weightWWW, tensionTTTstatic frictionFfF_fFf​and normal forceNNN;

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3e083eeb-2ac3-45c1-a54c-95d8955270d7/images/e14de16f-c457-499c-989c-258323ec83e0/PH0559Q.png)

Weight has two components parallel to the inclineWhW_hWh​and perpendicular to the inclineWvW_vWv​;Wh=mgsin⁡(30°)=(3.0)(9.81)(0.5)=15W_h=mg\sin(30°)=(3.0)(9.81)(0.5)=15Wh​=mgsin(30°)=(3.0)(9.81)(0.5)=15N down to the slopeThe tension balances the weight of the mass of 4.0 kg;T=mg=(4.0)(9.81)=39T=mg=(4.0)(9.81)=39T=mg=(4.0)(9.81)=39NThe forces parallel to the incline must cancel each other;Wh+Ff=T15+Ff=39Ff=24N\begin{aligned}
 W_h+F_f&=T\\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 15+F_f&=39\\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 F_f&=24\textrm{ N}\\
 \end{aligned}Wh​+Ff​15+Ff​Ff​​=T=39=24N​By using the equation of static friction;Ff=μRμ(3.0)(9.81)cos⁡(30°)=24μ=0.96\begin{aligned}
 F_f&=\mu R\\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 \mu(3.0)(9.81)\cos(30°)&=24\\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 \mu&=0.96\\
 \end{aligned}Ff​μ(3.0)(9.81)cos(30°)μ​=μR=24=0.96​The dynamic friction =≪μR=(0.40)(3.0)(9.81)cos⁡30°=≫10≪N≫\ll\mu R=(0.40)(3.0)(9.81)\cos30°=\gg 10 \ll N\gg≪μR=(0.40)(3.0)(9.81)cos30°=≫10≪N≫✓\checkmark✓aaa=≪14.7−10.23=≫\ll\dfrac{14.7-10.2}{3}=\gg≪314.7−10.2​=≫1.5 m s−2^{-2}−2✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:There are only two forces that act on the mass parallel to the incline. They are components of the weightWhW_hWh​down to the slope and dynamic frictionFfF_fFf​up the slope. The dynamic friction;Ff=μR=(0.40)(3.0)(9.81)cos⁡(30°)=10F_f=\mu R=(0.40)(3.0)(9.81)\cos(30°)=10Ff​=μR=(0.40)(3.0)(9.81)cos(30°)=10NFnet=maF_{net}=maFnet​=ma14.7−10.2=3.0a14.7-10.2=3.0a14.7−10.2=3.0aa=1.5a=1.5a=1.5m s−2^{-2}−2displacement of the mass =≪1.0sin⁡(30o)=≫2.0≪m≫\ll \dfrac{1.0}{\sin(30^o)} = \gg 2.0 \ll\textrm{m}\gg≪sin(30o)1.0​=≫2.0≪m≫✓\checkmark✓v=≪(2)(1.5)(2.0)=≫2.4≪m s−1≫v = \ll\sqrt{(2)(1.5)(2.0)}=\gg 2.4 \ll\textrm{m s}^{-1}\ggv=≪(2)(1.5)(2.0)​=≫2.4≪m s−1≫✓\checkmark✓ORHeat lost due to friction =≪Ffd=(10)(2.0)=≫20≪J≫\ll F_f d=(10)(2.0)=\gg 20\ll\textrm{J}\gg≪Ff​d=(10)(2.0)=≫20≪J≫✓\checkmark✓vvv=≪(2)(9.0)(3.0)=≫\ll \sqrt{\dfrac{(2)(9.0)}{(3.0)}}=\gg≪(3.0)(2)(9.0)​​=≫2.4 m s−1^{-1}−1✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The overall displacement s of the mass when it displaced 1.0 m vertically;s=1.0sin⁡(30o)=2.0s=\dfrac{1.0}{\sin(30^o)}=2.0s=sin(30o)1.0​=2.0mBy using a suvat equation;v2=u2+2asv^2=u^2+2asv2=u2+2aswhileu=0u=0u=0,a=1.5a=1.5a=1.5m s−2^{-2}−2, ands=2.0s=2.0s=2.0mv2=(2)(1.5)(2.0)=6.0v^2=(2)(1.5)(2.0)=6.0v2=(2)(1.5)(2.0)=6.0v=2.4v=2.4v=2.4m s−1^{-1}−1This question can be also done with the conservation of energy approach;The energy dissipated due to friction isQ=Ffd=(10)(2)=20Q=F_f d=(10)(2)=20Q=Ff​d=(10)(2)=20Jand the change in gravitational potential energy can be found byΔEp=mgΔh=(3.0)(9.81)(1.0)=29\Delta E_p=mg\Delta h=(3.0)(9.81)(1.0)=29ΔEp​=mgΔh=(3.0)(9.81)(1.0)=29JThe gravitational potential energy was converted to thermal energy from friction and kinetic energy, therefore29=ΔEk+2029=\Delta E_k+2029=ΔEk​+20ΔEk=9.0\Delta E_k=9.0ΔEk​=9.0JSolving for speed givesΔEk=12mv2\Delta E_k=\frac{1}{2} mv^2ΔEk​=21​mv2v=2ΔEkmv=\sqrt{\dfrac{2\Delta E_k}{m}}v=m2ΔEk​​​v=(2)(9.0)(3.0)=2.4v=\sqrt{\dfrac{(2)(9.0)}{(3.0)}}=2.4v=(3.0)(2)(9.0)​​=2.4m s−1^{-1}−1

list.title: Question 48
list.content:
The graph shows the variation of lengthlllof a spring of original lengthL0L_0L0​as it is stretched to lengthLLLby a variable forceFFF.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/87242baa-b4ea-481a-b7d4-e239d02e6e23/images/5b8d978a-39bc-473d-9327-9a5b73474a58/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%204.11.33%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

The work done against the spring is represented by which of the following?A.\hspace{1em}The area marked X.B.\hspace{1em}The area marked Y.C.\hspace{1em}The area marked Z.D.\hspace{1em}The sum of the areas marked Y and Z
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:SinceW=F⋅sW = F \cdot sW=F⋅s, work can be found from areas on the graph. Because the axes are switched, the area must be found between using the length axis as the base. Only the triangular area contained between the graph and the length axis fromLLLtoL0L_0L0​represents the work done.

list.title: Question 49
list.content:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a07393e2-13b6-4cef-b722-c8894c128a01/images/c42117b3-7ee7-46c1-b4b9-bd159e6e5cb7/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%204.01.21%E2%80%AFPM.png)

A cart of massmmmenters a smooth vertical loop the loop of radiusRRRwith a horizontal speeduuuat the bottom of the track, as shown. The cart just manages to stay in contact with the track at the top most point of its path.Its speed at the bottom of the loopuuu, is given by:A.\hspace{1em}u=5gRu=\sqrt{5gR}u=5gR​B.\hspace{1em}u=4gRu=\sqrt{4gR}u=4gR​C.\hspace{1em}u=gRu=\sqrt{gR}u=gR​D.\hspace{1em}u=2gRu=\sqrt{2gR}u=2gR​
list.markScheme:
AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Conservation of energy:Ek+EpE_k + E_pEk​+Ep​at the bottom of the circle =Ek+EpE_k + E_pEk​+Ep​at the top of the circle.(I)\hspace{0.8em}12mu2+0=12mv2+mg(2R)\dfrac{1}{2}mu^2+0=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2+mg(2R)21​mu2+0=21​mv2+mg(2R)u2=v2+4gR\hspace{2.2em}u^2=v^2+4gRu2=v2+4gRCentripetal force at the top of the loop comes from the weight of the cart and the normal reaction force from the track which both point downwards, towards the centre of the circle at that point. Because the question states that the car just keeps contact with the the track, we can assume that the normal reaction force is effectively zero.Writing Newton’s second law at that point gives:mg+N=m(v2R)mg+0=m(v2R)v2=gR\begin{aligned}
\hspace{0.7cm} mg+N &=m\bigg(\frac{v^2}{R}\bigg) \\
\hspace{1em}\\
mg+0 &= m\bigg(\frac{v^2}{R}\bigg) \\
\hspace{1em}\\
{v^2}&= gR \\
\end{aligned}mg+Nmg+0v2​=m(Rv2​)=m(Rv2​)=gR​Substituting this result into (I) givesu2=gR+4gRu^2=gR+4gRu2=gR+4gRu=5gRu=\sqrt{5gR}u=5gR​

list.title: Question 50
list.content:
A mass,mmm, is attached to a spring (of negligible mass) of spring constantkkkon a smooth horizontal surface. The mass is initially pulled a distance,xxx, from its equilibrium position on the surface and released. At the point where the mass has moved a distancex3\dfrac{x}{3}3x​from its starting point, the speed of the mass isvvv.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b62c54b1-8f15-4ea7-ab55-a6675f1dc82c/images/e7a41f5e-ccae-4876-b0f5-a8c7b6679199/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%205.22.20%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Which expression is equal tokkk?A.\hspace{1em}9mv25x2\dfrac{9mv^2}{5x^2}5x29mv2​B.\hspace{1em}5x29mv2\dfrac{5x^2}{9mv^2}9mv25x2​C.\hspace{1em}9mv28x2\dfrac{9mv^2}{8x^2}8x29mv2​D.\hspace{1em}8x29mv2\dfrac{8x^2}{9mv^2}9mv28x2​
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Since there is no energy loss due to friction or external forces, the mechanical energy of the system remains constant. After the release of the mass, some of the elastic potential energy of the system is transferred to the kinetic energy of the mass. The extension of the spring at the moment the mass covers the distance ofx3\dfrac{x}{3}3x​:x−x3=2x3x-\dfrac{x}{3}=\dfrac{2x}{3}x−3x​=32x​The energy elastic potential energy decreasedΔEH\Delta E_HΔEH​after release to the point where the mass covers the distance ofx3\dfrac{x}{3}3x​:ΔEH=12kx2−12k(2x3)2=12k5x29\Delta E_H=\dfrac{1}{2}kx^2-\dfrac{1}{2}k\Bigl(\dfrac{2x}{3}\Bigr)^2=\dfrac{1}{2}k\dfrac{5x^2}{9}ΔEH​=21​kx2−21​k(32x​)2=21​k95x2​The energy is transferred to kinetic energyEKE_KEK​:EK=12mv2=12k5x29E_K=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2=\dfrac{1}{2}k\dfrac{5x^2}{9}EK​=21​mv2=21​k95x2​k=9mv25x2k=\dfrac{9mv^2}{5x^2}k=5x29mv2​

list.title: Question 51
list.content:
A massmmmattached to a string is moving in a horizontal circular motion as shown. The tension on the string isTTT, and the angle with the vertical isθ\thetaθ.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1f897e16-36d2-4eba-9082-d03dcb67e4bf/images/a13df1c4-6075-41b6-b663-837340c74c7f/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2010.29.13%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

Below are three statements about this motion:I.\hspace{1em}Centripetal force =mgmgmgtan⁡(θ)\tan(\theta)tan(θ).II.\hspace{0.8em}Total gravitational and kinetic energy of the mass is constant.III.\hspace{0.4em}If the rope is cut, the mass will fall downwards with a straight line trajectory.Which of the statements are correct?A.\hspace{1em}Only IB.\hspace{1em}I and IIC.\hspace{1em}II and IIID.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Statement I is correct:\hspace{3em}TTTcos⁡(θ)\cos(\theta)cos(θ)=mgmgmg,  which givesT=mgcos⁡(θ)T = \dfrac{mg}{\cos(\theta)}T=cos(θ)mg​\hspace{3em}centripetal force (FcF_cFc​) =TTTsin⁡(θ)\sin(\theta)sin(θ)Substitutingmgcos⁡(θ)\dfrac{mg}{\cos(\theta)}cos(θ)mg​forTTTin the second equation:\hspace{3em}Fc=mgF_c=mgFc​=mgsin⁡(θ)cos⁡(θ)\dfrac{\sin(\theta)}{\cos(\theta)}cos(θ)sin(θ)​=mgmgmgtan⁡(θ)\tan(\theta)tan(θ).Statement II is correct:The path is a horizontal plane, therefore gravitational potential energy is constant. No work is done, therefore kinetic energy is constant. Total mechanical energy is constant.Statement III is false:The mass has a horizontal velocity during this motion. When the rope is cut, the only force will be the weight, therefore it will move in a projectile motion starting with a horizontal velocity, following a vertical parabolic path (not fall directly downwards).

list.title: Question 52

A race car starts to race on a straight horizontal race track from rest. \hspace{1em}C.D.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e181572b-0067-44df-b66a-5b47ae57facb/images/d3f1ff93-c969-4bc7-a273-166a6e0c4c49/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%201.43.27%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e181572b-0067-44df-b66a-5b47ae57facb/images/16e4fc70-5030-4221-b643-8987cfde7073/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%201.43.42%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The power from the engine to overcome the resistive forceFresF_{res}Fres​at any given instant is found from the formulaPres=FresvP_{res} = F_{res}vPres​=Fres​vWherevvvis the speed of the car.At the start of the motion, both the resistive force and speed are zero, and both of these increase with time. Because of the increasing resistive force, however, eventually a terminal speed will be reached whereFresF_{res}Fres​andvvv, and thereforePresP_{res}Pres​, are all constant.

list.title: Question 53
list.content:
A small ball of massmmmis attached to a string and moves in a vertical circular path of radiusrrr.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6a188747-1392-42b0-ac39-2dd62e548fe1/images/467e28b4-d9f5-4434-b96a-c3bc44003cdd/PH0358-1.png)

What is the minimum velocityvvvat the lowest point of the path for the ball to continue moving in a circular path at top of the circle?A.\hspace{1em}2mgr2mgr2mgrB.\hspace{1em}mgr2\dfrac{mgr}{2}2mgr​C.\hspace{1em}2gr\sqrt{2gr}2gr​D.\hspace{1em}5gr\sqrt{5gr}5gr​
list.markScheme:
DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6a188747-1392-42b0-ac39-2dd62e548fe1/images/414637ea-ccfa-4155-8c44-f38f9db344d1/PH0358_2.png)

To calculate the minimum value of velocity at the lowest point, we need to calculate the minimum kinetic energy.At the lowest point, the total energy is only kinetic energy and the potential energy is zero.From the law of conservation of energy,Total energy at the top = Total energy at the lowest pointAt the top the minimum speed for a circular path to be maintained occurs when the centripetal force = weight of the ballmv2r=mg\dfrac{mv^2}{r}=mg \hspace{2em}rmv2​=mggivingv2=gr\hspace{2em} v^2=grv2=grTotal energy at the top = kinetic energy + gravitational potential energyET=12mv2+mghE_T=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2+mghET​=21​mv2+mghWhereh=2rh=2rh=2rbecause it is equal to the diameter of the circular path.ET=12mgr+mg(2r)=52mgrE_T=\dfrac{1}{2}mgr+mg\left(2r\right)=\dfrac{5}{2}mgrET​=21​mgr+mg(2r)=25​mgrAt the lowest point,ET=EK=12mv252mgr=12mv2v2=5grv=5gr\begin{aligned}
\hspace{1.5em}E_T=E_K&=\frac{1}{2}mv^2\\
\hspace{1em}\\
\frac{5}{2}mgr&=\frac{1}{2}mv^2\\
\hspace{1em}\\
v^2&=5gr\\
\hspace{1em}\\
v&=\sqrt{5gr}
\end{aligned}ET​=EK​25​mgrv2v​=21​mv2=21​mv2=5gr=5gr​​

list.title: Question 54
list.content:
An object of massmmmwith a speed of3.03.03.0m s−1^{-1}−1collides horizontally with a stationary box of mass2m2m2m. After the collision, the object and the box move together.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3cf2be14-0daf-4355-93ab-e26bc35e2097/images/2d97cc7f-9cc9-48f4-bbbe-7367adb6bfac/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2012.46.16%E2%80%AFPM.png)

The friction acting on the box and the object is6.06.06.0N.Which expression gives total distance travelled by the combined objects before coming to rest after the collision?A.m16\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{m}{16}16m​B.m12\hspace{1em}  		\dfrac{m}{12}12m​C.m8\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{m}{8}8m​D.m4\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{m}{4}4m​
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:By using the principle of conservation of momentum, the combined velocityvvvof the object and the box can be found.The total momentum of the object and the box before the collision =3m3m3mThe total momentum of the object and the box after the collision =(2m+m)v=3mv(2m+m)v=3mv(2m+m)v=3mv3m=3mv3m=3mv3m=3mv1.0ms−1=v1.0\ \ce{m s}^{-1}=v1.0ms−1=vUsing conservation of energyInitial kinetic energy of the system =12mv2=12(3m)12=1.5m\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2 = \dfrac{1}{2}(3m)1^2 = 1.5m21​mv2=21​(3m)12=1.5mFinal kinetic energy of the system = 0Therefore work doen by friction isW=3m2W =\dfrac{3m}{2}W=23m​W=FsW = FsW=Fs3m2=6s\dfrac{3m}{2} = 6 s23m​=6ss=m4s = \dfrac{m}{4}s=4m​

list.title: Question 55
list.content:
A trapeze artist is swinging from positionAto positionCas shown in the diagram.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/59fccbf9-fd3e-4471-9a50-940ba5f27060/images/c0aaf0a7-fc7e-4d09-a5db-088c89da3945/PH0634a.png)

[Source: Image created using Images by OpenClipart-Vectors from Pixabay - https ://pixabay.com]\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Image created using Images by OpenClipart-Vectors from Pixabay - https ://pixabay.com]}}[Source: Image created using Images by OpenClipart-Vectors from Pixabay - https ://pixabay.com]The combined mass of the artist and the swing is 70 kg, the length of the rope of the swing isLLLand the tension in the rope at positionBisTTT.Which expression gives the kinetic energy at positionB?A.L(T−700)2\hspace{1em} \ \dfrac{L\left(T-700\right)}{2}2L(T−700)​B.LT2\hspace{1em} \ \dfrac{LT}{2}2LT​C.LT\hspace{1em} \ LTLTD.L(T+700)2\hspace{1em} \ \dfrac{L\left(T+700\right)}{2}2L(T+700)​
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:At positionB, at the bottom of the circular path, the net force is\hspace{2em}∑F=T−mg=mv2r\sum F=T-mg=\dfrac{mv^2}{r}∑F=T−mg=rmv2​Then, the tension of the rope\hspace{2em}T=mv2r+mgT=\dfrac{mv^2}{r}+mgT=rmv2​+mgand\hspace{2em}mg=700Nmg=700 \ Nmg=700NThe kinetic energy at positionB\hspace{2em}Ek=12mv2E_k=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2Ek​=21​mv2Rearranging the formula giving the tension we can find an expression forv2v^2v2:\hspace{2em}v2=r(T−mg)mv^2=\dfrac{r\left(T-mg\right)}{m}v2=mr(T−mg)​\hspace{2em}v2=L(T−700)mv^2=\dfrac{L\left(T-700\right)}{m}v2=mL(T−700)​Then\hspace{2em}Ek=12m(L(T−700)m)=L(T−700)2E_k=\dfrac{1}{2}m\left(\dfrac{L\left(T-700\right)}{m}\right)=\dfrac{L\left(T-700\right)}{2}Ek​=21​m(mL(T−700)​)=2L(T−700)​

list.title: Question 56
list.content:
A roller coaster goes around the inside of a loop of radiusRRR, shown in the diagram. The combined mass of a car and the passengers isMMM.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6f95051c-3ef4-47b5-9d9c-d0de481dc43b/images/9e4d25ea-942a-4007-a457-e0e798b79f1f/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%205.33.30%E2%80%AFPM.png)

When the car is at its highest point, the normal reaction force of the track on the car is equal to half of the weight of the car and passengers.Which expression gives the kinetic energy at the top of the loop?A.\hspace{1em}0B.\hspace{1em}RMg4\dfrac{RMg}{4}4RMg​C.\hspace{1em}3RMg4\dfrac{3RMg}{4}43RMg​D.\hspace{1em}RMgRMgRMg
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:At the top of the loop, the centripetal force is the vector sum of the combined weight of the car and the passengers, and the normal force of the track on the car.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6f95051c-3ef4-47b5-9d9c-d0de481dc43b/images/16199394-207d-4ae6-a977-c0b888e9baa8/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%205.35.25%E2%80%AFPM.png)

\hspace{2em}Mv2R=Mg+0.5Mg=32Mg\dfrac{Mv^2}{R}=Mg+0.5Mg=\dfrac{3}{2}MgRMv2​=Mg+0.5Mg=23​Mg\hspace{2em}Mv2=32RMgMv^2=\dfrac{3}{2}RMgMv2=23​RMgSince the kinetic energy\hspace{2em}Ek=12Mv2E_k=\dfrac{1}{2}Mv^2Ek​=21​Mv2Then\hspace{2em}Ek=32RMg2=3RMG4E_k=\dfrac{\frac{3}{2}RMg}{2}=\dfrac{3RMG}{4}Ek​=223​RMg​=43RMG​

list.content:
An object is released from rest from a very high building. Air resistance is not negligible. Which of the following graphs shows the variation of the gravitational potential energyEpE_pEp​of the object with timettt?A.B.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/73997d7b-66ca-4a01-b295-7ddaa1874891/images/efd95959-c022-47ea-8cca-dde93d398cef/Screenshot%202025-05-26%20at%2010.55.50%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

\hspace{1cm}

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/73997d7b-66ca-4a01-b295-7ddaa1874891/images/cccdb404-3c1c-47e0-b2a4-f0f329339ed1/Screenshot%202025-05-26%20at%2010.55.55%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

\hspace{1cm}C.D.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/73997d7b-66ca-4a01-b295-7ddaa1874891/images/565b9e0b-6bad-43b8-a252-bf149f1421fc/Screenshot%202025-05-26%20at%2010.56.02%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/73997d7b-66ca-4a01-b295-7ddaa1874891/images/32dde9de-5839-4f64-957f-be1660271073/Screenshot%202025-05-26%20at%2010.56.07%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:ΔEp=mgΔh\Delta E_p = mg\Delta hΔEp​=mgΔhDue to downward acceleration due to gravity, the rate of decrease of gravitational potential energy with time must increase – slope must become steeper as it speeds up. For slow speeds and low air resistance, the height follows the functionΔh=12at2\Delta h=\dfrac{1}{2}at^2Δh=21​at2After the object reaches terminal velocity, the rate of decrease of gravitational potential energy is constant with time.

list.title: Question 58
list.content:
Two masses of222kg and444kg are connected with a string that passes over a pulley. They are released from rest. Energy is lost in the pulley due to friction.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a3935bc0-26a9-423f-98b1-8976d18dc4d7/images/ba606c7f-40fe-40a9-9904-adf078fef49f/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%205.43.14%E2%80%AFPM.png)

When the222kg mass has gained a gravitational potential energy ofEEE, the444kg mass has a kinetic energy of12E\dfrac{1}{2}E21​E. How much energy has been lost to friction up to that point in time?A.E4\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{E}{4}4E​B.E2\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{E}{2}2E​C.E\hspace{1em}  	EED.2E\hspace{1em}  	2E2E
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Since both of the masses are connected by the string, they should have the same speed and vertical displacement.Because bothEpE_pEp​andEkE_kEk​are proportional to the mass of the object,Gravitational potential energy loss of the mass of444kg will be twice the gain of the small mass, which would be2E2E2ESimilarly, the kinetic energy of the mass of2kg2\, kg2kgwill be half of that of the4kg4\,kg4kgwhich givesE4\dfrac{E}{4}4E​Due to the principle of energy conservation;The potential energy lost by the mass of444kg is equal to the sum ofThe potential energy gained by the mass of222kg(2E)(2E)(2E)energy lost due to friction(U)(U)(U)kinetic energy of the mass of222kg(E4)\bigg(\dfrac{E}{4}\bigg)(4E​)and444kg(E2)\bigg(\dfrac{E}{2}\bigg)(2E​)2E=E+U+E4+E22E\ =E+U+\dfrac{E}{4}+\dfrac{E}{2}2E=E+U+4E​+2E​U=E4U=\dfrac{E}{4}U=4E​

list.title: Question 59
list.content:
A metal ball of massmmmis released from a height ofhhhabove a massless platform attached to a vertical spring.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b5cb7aae-5a20-4225-b7e7-576050644152/images/83f09acf-9277-45e6-9188-189b131b1bb6/PH0565.png)

[Source: Created with chemix - https://chemix.org/]\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Created with chemix - https://chemix.org/]}}[Source: Created with chemix - https://chemix.org/]The spring constant of the spring is given bymgh\dfrac{mg}{h}hmg​. The ball hits the spring and compresses it. When the spring is compressed by a distancehhh, what is the speed of the ball?(Energy transfer only happens between spring and ball and the kinetic energy of the spring can be ignored)A.2h\hspace{1em}  	\sqrt{2h}2h​B.2gh\hspace{1em}  	\sqrt{2gh}2gh​C.3h\hspace{1em}  	\sqrt{3h}3h​D.3gh\hspace{1em}  \sqrt{3gh}3gh​
list.markScheme:
DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:When the initial position and final position of the ball are compared in terms of energy, it can be realized that the decrease in gravitational potential energyEpE_pEp​of the ball equals to increase in kinetic energyEkE_{k}Ek​of the ball and the increase in elastic potential energyEHE_HEH​of the spring. Additionally, the total decrease in height of the ball is2h2h2h.ΔEp=Ek+EHmg(2h)=12mv2+12mghh212mv2=mg(2h)−12mghmv2=4mgh−mghmv2=3mghv=3gh\begin{aligned}
\Delta E_p&=E_k +E_H\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
mg(2h)&=\frac{1}{2}mv^2+\frac{1}{2}\frac{mg}{h}h^2 \\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
\frac{1}{2}mv^2&=mg(2h)-\frac{1}{2}mgh\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
mv^2&=4mgh-mgh\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
mv^2&=3mgh\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
v&=\sqrt{3gh}\\
\end{aligned}ΔEp​mg(2h)21​mv2mv2mv2v​=Ek​+EH​=21​mv2+21​hmg​h2=mg(2h)−21​mgh=4mgh−mgh=3mgh=3gh​​Therefore, the answer is D.
